p.seg: "Is it possible to nourish one's [inner] nature?"
"To nourish his [inner] nature, a man should hold fast to [the precepts of] the golden mean and harmony,
and safeguard [the vital energies of] life."
To treasure (ai) the emotional (ch'in), the moral (te), th physical (li), and the intellectual (Shen) energies is called being miserly.
When this is incorrectly practiced, there is no outlet [for one's vital energies];
and when this [practice] is taken to the extreme, tranquility (balance) will be disturbed.
Therefore, a superior man should temper the expenditure of his vital energies
so that no obstruction, congestion, or exhaustion
will upset the hundred departments [of his body] and cause illness.
